text: There's no country today that is more
free and democratic than the Democratic
People's Republic of Korea. And I would
say that in a New York Times interview.
I would say that at any setting, I have
to say it because it's true.
Sure, I know it was a provocative thing
to say, but I think it is true. As I
mentioned in the 5-second clip, which
was taken from a 2 and a half hour
stream, as a philosophy professor, I
come from a tradition that thinks about
morality in social terms. Thinks about
morality in terms of ethical life, the
ability to achieve rational uh mutual
recognition between individuals mediated
through rational social institutions and
the highest of which of course would be
the state. It's a tradition that
situates me within
um you know other thinkers like
Aristotle, Hegel and Marx who are
thinking about moral problems and
dilemmas situated not just in the
aspirations of individual flourishing
but social flourishing and this sort of
dialectical and reciprocal relationship
between the individual and the social
such that to have the conditions for
human flourishing at the individual
level, you also need to meet them at the
social level. Now, I think that in terms
of freedom, that's really the substance
of freedom is having ethical life as uh
Hegel would say. In German, the term is
sitkite. I think those conditions are
much more plentifully met in the
Democratic People's Republic of Korea,
given that it is a socialist country
than it is in any of the capitalist
countries in the West. As far as
democracy, I know this might sound like
another bold claim considering that here
in the west we consider democracy to be
multi-party democracy and elections.
Even though traditionally for the Greeks
who were the first people to theorize
democracy, elections were a method of
politics that was rooted in aris in in
the aristocracy and parties themselves
are an invention of something like a
millennium after democracy itself. So
our conception of democracy is already
very warped. But etmologically democracy
is a combination of two words. It's
demos which means popular uh folks,
common people uh what we would use as
masses today and kattos which means the
ability to exert power over to rule.
Really democracy what it means is what
in the Marxist tradition we label as the
dictatorship of the proletariat. the
ability to have power in the hands of
common people, in the hands of the
working class. And given that the
Democratic People's Republic of Korea is
a socialist country, I think that it is
therefore more plentifully democratic,
more plentifully able to exert a form of
popular dictatorship, a dictatorship of
the people than what we have in the
capitalist west. So there you go, a
little bit of a longer explanation for
why I said the DPRK is the most
democratic and free country in the
